expectations:
- MUST be in US English (teaching Spanish)
      - Should cover Spanish-specific grammar structures (ser vs estar, subjunctive, preterite vs imperfect, etc.)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes relevant to everyday Spanish (food, travel, family, etc.)
      - Should cover communication scenarios (greetings, ordering food, asking directions, etc.)

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model B provides an excellent, comprehensive curriculum with ~103 chapters that covers A1 through C2 thoroughly. It follows prompt rules very well: no skill-based chapters, no culture chapters, no career/professional chapters, no exam prep, no literature/media chapters. The granularity is excellent — it separates grammar topics well (e.g., preterite regular vs irregular, direct vs indirect object pronouns, multiple subjunctive chapters). Spanish-specific grammar is thoroughly covered: ser vs estar (split across two chapters), preterite vs imperfect, subjunctive across 8+ chapters, por vs para, personal a, uses of se, conditional sentences, como si constructions, reported speech, passive constructions, periphrastic verbs, etc. Vocabulary themes are well covered (food, shopping, travel, health, weather, technology, housing). Communication scenarios are included (complaints, invitations, opinions, agreement/disagreement). The interleaving of grammar and vocabulary is natural. Descriptions are concise and avoid fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. Titles are clean and professional. The progression from beginner to advanced is logical and well-ordered. Minor notes: 'Accent Marks and Spelling Traps' could be seen as borderline skill-based, but it's really about orthographic rules which are content. Overall this is the strongest curriculum.

Model A provides ~85 chapters with excellent coverage from A1 to C2. It follows prompt rules very well — no forbidden chapter types appear. Spanish-specific grammar is thoroughly addressed: ser & estar, preterite, imperfect, subjunctive (multiple chapters including present, past, perfect, stance), conditional sentences, passive constructions, reported speech, por vs para, uses of se (split into two chapters), periphrastic verbs. Vocabulary themes are covered (food, family, weather, clothing, health, travel, shopping, hobbies). The interleaving is good. Descriptions are concise and mostly avoid fluff. Titles are clean and specific. Advanced topics like word formation, abstract expression, precision & hedging, pragmatics & persuasion, and native-like coherence round out the C2 level. Some chapters like 'Everyday Work Talk' might seem borderline career but it's framed as general vocabulary which is acceptable. The curriculum is slightly less granular than Model B in some areas (e.g., object pronouns combined rather than separated, commands in one chapter rather than two), but it compensates with excellent advanced-level chapters. Very strong overall.

Model F provides ~72 chapters with good A1-C2 coverage. It follows most prompt rules well. Grammar coverage is solid: present tense (regular and irregular separated), preterite, imperfect, preterite vs imperfect, perfect tenses, future, conditional, subjunctive (present, past, perfect), reported speech, passive voice, relative clauses, comparatives. Spanish-specific topics are covered. Vocabulary themes include food, shopping, travel, health, emergencies, technology, education. However, there are some issues: 'Conversational Fluency & Repair Strategies' is borderline skill-based (fluency strategies, fillers, turn-taking). 'Complex Discourse Production & Register Integration' also leans skill-based. 'Specialized Registers & Terminology' mentioning 'medical, legal, technical' domain-specific vocabulary could be seen as professional/career territory. 'Slang, Taboo Language & Register Constraints' is borderline. Some descriptions use slightly more verbose phrasing. The interleaving of grammar and vocabulary is decent but the later chapters cluster heavily toward grammar/advanced structures. Still a solid curriculum overall.

Model D provides ~96 chapters with broad coverage. Grammar and vocabulary coverage is generally good. Spanish-specific topics are addressed: ser vs estar, preterite vs imperfect, subjunctive (multiple chapters), por vs para, conditional sentences, reported speech, etc. However, there are several rule violations: 'Letters & Formal Correspondence' is borderline skill/writing-based. 'Presentations & Structured Discourse' is skill-based (oral presentation skills). 'Summarizing & Paraphrasing' is clearly a skill-based chapter. 'Complex Texts & Critical Analysis' is explicitly a reading/skill-based chapter and also mentions 'opinion pieces, editorials' which borders on media/literature. 'Fluency & Spontaneous Expression' is skill-based. 'Negotiation & Diplomacy' borders on career/professional. Some vocabulary chapters like 'Law, Government & Civic Life', 'Economics & Global Issues', and 'Science & Technology' are very broad domain chapters that could be seen as acceptable vocabulary expansion, though they push boundaries. The descriptions are generally clean but some are slightly verbose. The ordering is logical but the multiple violations of prompt rules significantly impact the score.

Model C provides ~75 chapters. While it covers core grammar and vocabulary, there are several prompt violations. 'News & Current Events' — vocabulary for journalism and media borders on media chapters which are forbidden. 'Arts & Entertainment' — theater, cinema, music, visual arts is explicitly a culture/media chapter and is forbidden. 'Crime & Justice' — legal vocabulary, law enforcement, courts is specialized/professional vocabulary. 'Science & Research' — academic vocabulary, scientific method is borderline professional. 'Politics & Society' — government structures, elections, civic duties is borderline. 'Global Issues & Diplomacy' — international relations, human rights, treaties is professional/career territory. 'Abstract Concepts & Philosophy' is borderline. 'Complex Texts & Critical Analysis' is explicitly a skill-based chapter (reading). 'Fluency & Spontaneous Expression' is skill-based (filler words, turn-taking, natural rhythm). Multiple forbidden chapter types appear, which is a significant penalty. The grammar coverage is decent but somewhat less comprehensive than top models. Descriptions are generally clean. The violations are numerous enough to substantially lower the score.

Model E provides only ~42 chapters, which is notably fewer than other models and raises concerns about comprehensiveness. While it covers core grammar (present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional, subjunctive, reported speech, passive voice) and basic vocabulary themes (food, family, health, travel, shopping, weather), the coverage is insufficient for a complete A1-C2 curriculum. Many important topics are missing or insufficiently covered: no dedicated chapters for reflexive verb depth, no possessives/demonstratives chapter, no questions/interrogatives chapter, limited subjunctive coverage (only 4-5 chapters vs 8+ in better models), no dedicated chapter for uses of se, limited vocabulary themes at advanced levels, no word formation/diminutives, no discourse markers, no relative clauses with prepositions, minimal communication scenario chapters. 'Abstract Concepts & Philosophy' is a borderline inclusion. The descriptions are clean and concise, titles follow guidelines. But the curriculum simply isn't comprehensive enough — a learner finishing this would have significant gaps. The prompt explicitly requires the 'most complete, extensive, and comprehensive' curriculum, and 42 chapters falls well short of that goal.

Model A is flawless. It strictly follows all negative constraints, avoiding skill-based, culture, career, and media chapters. The chapter progression from A1 to C2 is incredibly thorough, well-paced, and perfectly categorizes content into grammar, vocabulary, and communication scenarios. The descriptions are perfectly concise (using noun phrases) and avoid all fluff verbs. It correctly interprets the prompt's nuances, such as ensuring the work-related chapter explicitly excludes 'professional specialization' to adhere to the career constraint.

Model B is exceptionally comprehensive and well-structured, rivaling Model A in depth and granularity. However, it includes a chapter on 'Accent Marks and Spelling Traps' which covers spelling confusions (b/v, ll/y) and punctuation. This borders on violating the explicit instructions not to include 'writing skills' or 'alphabet and sounds' chapters for Latin-script languages. Otherwise, it is an excellent curriculum.

Model E follows all instructions and successfully avoids all forbidden topics. It is a very solid curriculum. It scores slightly lower than Models A and B because it is a bit less comprehensive (fewer chapters for a complete A1-C2 journey) and its descriptions occasionally use fluff verbs like 'Mastering' and 'Distinguishing', which the prompt asked to avoid.

Model F provides a very detailed curriculum but misses the mark on a few negative constraints. Chapter 69 explicitly covers 'high-level professional... domains (medical, legal, technical)', which violates the rule against career/professional chapters. Additionally, it includes a meta-linguistic chapter on 'False Friends & L1 Interference', which isn't a true content domain. It also mentions reports and presentations, edging into writing/speaking skills.

Model C has a good structure but explicitly violates multiple negative constraints. Chapter 50 covers 'cinema, music', which directly violates the rules stating 'NO culture chapters — no... music' and 'NO literature or media chapters — no film'. Chapter 47 also touches on news media, which is explicitly forbidden.

Model D fails the most critical negative constraint: 'NO skill-based chapters'. It explicitly includes chapters dedicated to reading and writing skills, such as Chapter 70 ('Writing and understanding formal and informal letters'), Chapter 71 ('structuring essays'), Chapter 79 ('Summarizing texts'), and Chapter 83 ('Advanced reading of opinion pieces'). As stated in the prompt, these skills must not be chapters because they are built into every lesson.

Strong overall compliance: all chapters are content-domain (grammar/vocab/scenarios), progression is clear from beginner to advanced without CEFR labels, and it covers Spanish-specific essentials (ser/estar, preterite vs imperfect, por/para, object pronouns/clitics, se, extensive subjunctive, reported speech, passive, discourse/pragmatics, advanced syntax). Titles/descriptions are mostly concise and avoid skill-based or culture/career/literature/test-prep chapters. Minor issues: a couple chapters drift toward meta/course context (“classroom/platform instructions”), and some late-stage chapters verge on skill-ish framing (“Native-Like Coherence”), but still primarily linguistic/discourse content and not explicitly banned skill categories.

Very comprehensive and well-structured, with excellent Spanish-specific grammar coverage (personal a, extensive se, broad subjunctive map incl. como si, sequence of tenses, clitic doubling, voseo/leísmo basics) plus many everyday scenarios. However it includes a clearly skill-based, explicitly forbidden chapter: “Accent Marks and Spelling Traps” (orthography/spelling is writing skill). Also includes “proverbs” inside an idioms chapter title/description, which is not banned per se but edges toward culture; the spelling chapter is the main compliance break.

Broad and generally accurate coverage with good progression and many advanced grammar/discourse topics. Still, it violates prompt constraints by including multiple career/professional or specialized-domain chapters: “Work & Occupations (General Vocabulary)” (gray area but still career-themed), “Public Services & Administrative Language” (arguably institutional but acceptable), and especially “Specialized Registers & Terminology” (explicitly high-level professional domains). Also includes “Conversational Fluency & Repair Strategies,” which is more skill-based (fluency strategies) than a content domain. Strong content, but notable forbidden-topic drift.

Clean and compliant (no explicit skill/culture/career/media/test-prep chapters), and covers core Spanish grammar (ser/estar, past contrasts, subjunctive, por/para, pronouns, passive/se, reported speech). But it’s not sufficiently extensive for “best in the world” A1–C2 mastery: limited scenarios, thin advanced syntax/discourse/pragmatics, and missing many high-level structures (detailed relative/connector systems, advanced se/clitics, modality/stance, register management depth, etc.).

Good breadth and progression through many core areas, but contains multiple explicit violations: career/professional content (“Occupations & Work”), skill-based/writing-focused chapters (“Letters & Formal Correspondence,” “Summarizing & Paraphrasing,” “Complex Texts & Critical Analysis”), and arguably media-like/genre analysis via “Complex Texts & Critical Analysis.” Also includes “Proverbs & Sayings,” which leans cultural. Despite strong grammar coverage, these are major prompt breaches.

Includes several clearly forbidden culture/media/career-adjacent domains as standalone chapters: “News & Current Events” (media), “Arts & Entertainment” (media/culture), plus broad civic/politics/legal/economy topics (“Politics & Society,” “Crime & Justice,” “Economy & Finance”), which go beyond everyday vocabulary themes and veer into non-language topical curricula. While it has solid grammar coverage, these violations and topic drift make it much less aligned with the prompt.
